awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to carry out a systematic study of vortical flows incorporating buoyancy effects, including the effects of gravity, density differences and surface tension.  Explicit calculations of the motion of vortices in the presence of density differences and surface tension will develop understanding of fundamental fluid processes.  Potential applications include a number of technological and geophysical situations, such as volcano vortex rings, cavitation, and flows around helicopter rotors and wind turbins. The project brings together researchers with complementary skills and experience in vortex dynamics and variable-density flows, and begins a new collaborative effort with scientists in Japan, Spain and Great Britain. In addition to outreach, during a series of workshops, the PI and teachers will develop a curriculum unit focusing on the calculus relevant to physical principles, illustrated by examples from the proposed work and fluid mechanics more generally. 

Four sub-projects will be investigated. First, the stability of vortex filaments will be examined in the presence of density variations.  The case of rings and helices will be examined, since for these geometries solutions are known for the basic state.  Second, an asymptotically consistent model for the evolution of a thin-core vortex filament with density variations will be developed and implemented.  A formulation based on a force balance allows buoyancy and surface tension forces to be incorporated in a natural manner.  Third, contour dynamics methods for axisymmetric vortex rings with density differences will be developed.  This leads to the evolution of a vortex sheet on the boundary generated by baroclinic torques.  Fourth, a new approach to contour dynamics applicable to helical vortices will be introduced and implemented, giving new exact solutions to the problem.  The sub-projects are independent but related: each gives insight into features of the full problem.  The outcome should include advances in the understanding of vortical fluid flow, including new solutions, and in new reduced models of such flows.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of the project were to investigate vortical flows with density variations in the presence of gravity, with surface tension acting at the interfaces between fluids. Its goal was to develop understanding of fundamental fluid processes as exemplified by simple, yet realistic, configurations. Explicit calculations of the motion of non-trivial vortices in the presence of density differences and surface tension were obtained.

We considered the motion of thin-core vortex filaments with different density from the ambient fluid (e.g. hot smoke rings). Our study found that buoyancy increases the binormal velocity, so that a buoyant vortex ring will expand as it propagates up against gravity. We also considered "fat" axisymmetric vortex rings, both when the density difference inside the patch is small. This approach extended previous work that included swirl and magnetic fields, but the approach for significant vortex differences is more involved, since obtaining the governing equations requires using the full Euler equations.


We considered the parametric instability of a thin vortex ring with density variations and surface tension. Infinitesimal disturbances to the basic state of a vortex column are found to be neutrally stable and called Kelvin waves. However, if a vortex column is perturbed by a small parameter, to account for a small geometric or physical effect, Kelvin waves can interact with the perturbed basic state, potentially leading to parametric instabilities. Two common parametric instabilities for vortex rings have been discovered: one is the curvature instability; the other is the Moore-Saffman-Tsai-Widnall instability. The nature of these two instabilities in the presence of density differences was investigated in detail.


The preceding results examined density differences in incompressible flow. The effect of compressibility, including pressure and density variations, was examined in for unsteady point vortices in two-dimensional adiabatic flow.The goal of the work is to set up a dynamic system for point vortices. This was done using a Rayleigh-Jansen expansion and the method of Matched Asymptotic Expansions. The solution in the region between vortices was matched to solutions around each vortex core. The motion of the vortices is modified over long timescales. Examples are given for the co-rotating and co-propagating vortex pairs. The vortex solution matches to a far field in which acoustic waves are radiated for unsteady configurations.


Complementary projects examined geometric extensions of the previous work for which density differences could not be investigated. We considered vortex filaments with helical symmetry, obtaining equations for contour dynamics (a Lagrangian approach to the evolution of vortical regions governing by the motion of their boundaries) for this symmetry class. The equations of motion can be expressed as nonlinear evolution laws for two scalars: vorticity and along-helix velocity. We investigated the stability properties of a circular vortex patch along the axis of the helix in the presence of a vortex sheet and along-helix velocity. Equilibrium solutions for hollow vortices in straining flow in a corner were obtained by solving a free-boundary problem. Conformal maps from a canonical doubly connected annular domain to the physical plane combining the Schottky-Klein prime function with an appropriate algebraic map lead to a problem similar to Pocklington's propagating hollow dipole. The result was a two-parameter family of solutions depending on the corner angle and on the non-dimensional ratio of strain to circulation. Finally we examined the time evolution in two spatial dimensions of a double vorticity layer consisting of two contiguous, infinite fluid strips, each with uniform but generally differing vorticity. At leading order, closed nonlinear initial-value evolution equations were obtained describing the motion of the centre curve together with the time and spatial variation of each layer thickness. Analysis of the linear stability of the first-order equations to small-amplitude perturbations shows Kelvin-Helmholtz instability when the far-field fluid velocities on either side of the double layer are unequal.

Through the Physically Motivated Math Project (PMM), in collaboration with Dr. Osvaldo Soto (UC San Diego Math Project, Director), the PI helped a secondary physics teacher and five calculus teachers to design a two week unit for AP Calculus students to experience connections between physics and math after the AP exams, including written lesson plans aimed at motivating Calculus using Physics. From July 2018 to March 2019, Llewellyn Smith collaborated with project leaders, Dr. Osvaldo Soto (UC San Diego Math Project, Director) to prepare and plan for the project. PMM participants produced a short, shareable two-week unit with lesson plans piloted in late May 2019.
